Author: DanielBMarkham
Content:
F# is prominent on my radar.

If they will fully optimize non-mutable structures and functions across processors I think it's a game-changer for Microsoft. But having said that, it might be five years before all the pieces come together.

It has a lot of promise.

Author: tdavis
Content:
All the tables on the actual page (http://www.sfenitydev.com/AwesomeInc/) makes me think they used Arc; talk about amateur hour! ;)

But seriously... a broken dotNuke layout in a frame? Exactly who are they trying to attract here, web developers from 1995?

Author: astrec
Title: When will local truly be on the web?

Author: sqs
Content:
While they should have done a better job highlighting the interesting parts of the research, dig a bit deeper and you will find them. The PDF links at the bottom are worth reading.

(I know some people who worked on this stuff, and they are great people with lots of cool research and ideas.)

Author: tdavis
Content: I will second your recommendation of Programming Erlang: Software for a Concurrent World. It's quite good.

Author: sanj
Content:
I hadn't realized that the word had suddenly gotten narrowed down!

I spent then 90's at MIT and was indoctrinated with the term there. It was used referred to any clever solution (no pun intended) or trick, and most especially one that thumbed its nose at authority:

http://hacks.mit.edu/Hacks/by_year/1994/cp_car/

I'll stand by my usage: this qualifies admirably on both counts.

Author: Anon84
Title: Washington Post: Recommended Reading for Our Times

Author: randallsquared
Content: Not every phone does, but even those that do often have so few numbers in the PIN that it's basically window dressing security.  Are there phones that have 7-10 digit PINs?

Author: marvin
Content: "Flying cars" will never be created, the same way a road-running sailboat will never be created. But we could probably build an aircraft today that would serve most of the purposes a car does.
